 r22817 | tkorhon1@gmail.com | 2015-06-08 10:03:55 -0400 (Mon, 08 Jun 2015) | FDS Source: evacuation time step and synchronize is now working. EVAC_DT taken away from cons.f90 and evac.f90, it is just needed in main.f90. Main.f90 "Determine time step" changed. It has now not-EVACUATION_ONLY mask:       MESHES(NM)%DT_NEXT = MINVAL(DT_SYNC,MASK=.NOT.EVACUATION_ONLY)       T(NM) = MINVAL(T,MASK=.NOT.EVACUATION_ONLY) Now things seem to be running nicely. Plain fire calculation is not  changed, because the mask is then true for all meshes (just fire meshes).

 r21857 | tkorhon1@gmail.com | 2015-03-05 08:45:49 -0500 (Thu, 05 Mar 2015) | FDS Source: Divg.f90 chaned for evacuation. Now it has just fds6 style evacuation input support. This means that the Module DIVG routines are called just for evacuation meshes which have both evacuation_only=T and evacuation_grid=T. Old fds5 type evacuation input could have both present. Now the evacuation flow field calculation is done just for the main evacuation meshes (evacuation_only=T and evacuation_grid=T). The other evacuation meshes (evacuation_only=T and evacuation_grid=F) are just used in evac.f90 to see what the agents see (visibility meshes).  
 r21856 | tkorhon1@gmail.com | 2015-03-05 06:32:09 -0500 (Thu, 05 Mar 2015) | FDS Source: divg.f90 changed for evacuation. Now there is no divergence_part_1 for evacuation. Evacuation meshes are done in the same  divergence_part_1 than fire meshes. One if(evacuation_only(nm)) return is moved a little bit in init.f90 so that INTERPOLATED_MESH is allocated for evacuation meshes also.

 r19413 | daniel.haarhoff@gmail.com | 2014-05-28 07:03:02 -0400 (Wed, 28 May 2014) | FDS Source: radi: Move slice calculation to init.  Determine the wavefront slices for propagation during init_radiation.  The slices over which the cartesian radiation spread is parallelised were previously calculated during each individual radiation angle. This created serial overhead.  The SLICE_IJK array stores the wavefront slices for each of the eight propagation directions. The propagation direction index is essentially a conversion of the binary number consisting of the three stepping directions to decimal. The slices are stored in a serialised fashion since we know the total number of cells a priori and can allocate an array occordingly. The size of the individual slices depends on the meshes dimensions, but remains the same for each direction. Therefore two 1D arrays store the lower and upper bounds of each slice withing SLICE_IJK.  The propagation can then safely be parallelised within each slice.

 r18885 | daniel.haarhoff@gmail.com | 2014-04-04 18:00:40 -0400 (Fri, 04 Apr 2014) | FDS_Source: radi: Parallel radiation spread  Introduces a second version of the radiation propagation. This version removes the loop-carried dependencies of the original version and therefore allows parallelisation with OpenMP.  The loop-carried dependencies basically cause a wave to spread through the mesh, were the cells affected by the wave front are dependent upon the cells in the slice lying behind them.  To remove the loop-carried dependencies the indices of these slices are determined and stored in an array. Subsequently the loop over the cells in each slice can be safely parellelised with OpenMP.  To ease verification and code review this new version is only used if USE_OPENMP is .true.

 r18615 | daniel.haarhoff@gmail.com | 2014-03-10 08:54:17 -0400 (Mon, 10 Mar 2014) | FDS Source: radi: Make ZZ_GET an allocatable  This is akin to the prior change in divg.  r12802 | tkorhon1@gmail.com | 2012-09-21 10:31:02 -0400 (Fri, 21 Sep 2012) | FDS Source: Now the pressure zones are working for evacuation also so  there can be many sealed zones in the evacuation meshes.  r7167 | tkorhon1 | 2010-11-18 10:37:53 -0500 (Thu, 18 Nov 2010) | FDS Source: Now the evacuation input does not need anymore the additional evacuation meshes nor the evacuation vents.  But the old input still works and some mixed input works also.  r6640 | tkorhon1 | 2010-08-24 06:47:01 -0400 (Tue, 24 Aug 2010) | FDS Source: Added one .NOT.EVACUATION_ONLY(NM) to an IF statement in velo.f90. The evacuation part can now use the DEVC or CTRL information form the fire calcualation to trigger the movement of the agents. DEVC and CTRL has EVACUATION (logical) keyword in their namelists. If it is set then the activation information is saved in the CHID_evac.fed file and later used in the evacuation part. The new namelist EDEV is used to give some inputs how the agents use the DEVC/CTRL info, should still write this to the manual. If the EVACUATION=T for DEVC and CTRL namelists, it does not affect the fire calculation part, they work just the same way than EVACUATION=F, the only difference is that for EVACUATION=T some information is written to the disk.

If device activates (false ==> true) then all agents detect the fire, if they have done so yet (by the local smoke density and/or by the detection time distribution). Only EVACUATION=.TRUE. devices/controls are used for the agents.  
 r6576 | tkorhon1 | 2010-08-05 03:15:37 -0400 (Thu, 05 Aug 2010) | FDS+Evac Source: Added EVACUATION to READ_CTRL in read.f90 and also to the CTRL type in ctrl.f90.  If EVACUATION=.TRUE. in DECV or CTRL namelists then the "change state" information is written to the CHID_evac.fed file, so the evacuation part can use devices and/or controls to trigger movement.  Still to be done: and EDEV namelist to evac.f90, where you give parameters how the agents react for the different devices.

 r3496 | crogsch | 2009-03-14 08:07:54 -0400 (Sat, 14 Mar 2009) | FDS Source: Add Turb_Work arrays. In TURB.f90 ThreadChecker produces warnings, because in the original version of the VARDEN_DYNSMAG Subroutine WORK1-7 is used for pointers. This may cause a problem in compiling, because the WORK arrays are initialized 0:IBP1 and so on. Pointers use only 1:IBAR... from WORK1-7, so by calling the TEST_FILTER a possible problem with pointers could occure by copying values from the input-pointer to the output-pointer (PHIBAR = PHI). To prevent this possible problem, the WORK1-7 arrays are replaced by TURB_WORK13-19 arrays, which are initialized 1:IBAR..., so this possible problem is solved for further parallelization or compilation, because arrays and pointers have the same barriers. The ThreadChecker Warning to this problem was: "undefined in the serial code (original program)" 
 r3495 | crogsch | 2009-03-13 23:13:24 -0400 (Fri, 13 Mar 2009) | FDS Source: VELO.f90: Add OpenMP directives to calculation of MU and VELOCITY_FLUX Subroutine. The calculation of gravity components and Upwind/Downwind bias factors is placed at the beginning ot the subroutine. This will conserve parallelization time, because only one parallel region has to be opened. The " !$ IF... " statements are for debugging checks, because in the debug process every parallel region must be tested. If an official release should be compiled, this statements should be renamed to " !!!$ IF... " , thus they will be compiled like comments.

 r3100 | tkorhon1 | 2009-01-22 06:12:06 -0500 (Thu, 22 Jan 2009) | evac.f90: The EFF read error issue 605 is now handled even better. Now the calculation never stops for a read error.  If there is some read error, then the EFF fields are (re)calculated automatically. Just a warning is printed on the LU_EVACOUT channel (CHID_evac.out).  The earlier fix just checked the header material of the EFF file, but now the recalculate stuff is also added to the "bulk" read.

 r2755 | tkorhon1 | 2008-11-27 07:20:18 -0500 (Thu, 27 Nov 2008) | evac.f90: Cleaned a little bit and added better treatment for counterflows.  The default is the old algorithm, i.e., the results should be same as in previous versions, if no "new" inputs are given on the PERS-namelists.  The new algorithm should have "TAU_CHANGE_V0=0.1" on the PERS-namelist.  This (actually anything greater than zero) activates the new algorithms.  New algorithm is not yet documented and it is still "work in progress", i.e., I'm trying to find optimal default parameters for it.
